div.head: To the right honourable, the Earl of Dorset, etc.
div.p:
The uncivil ignorance of the people, had deprived this humble work of life; but that your lordship's approbation, stepped in, to succour it. Those many that came with resolution to dispraise (Knowing your lordship's judgement, to be powerful, above their malice) were either corrected to an understanding, or modesty: and this large benefit, hath betrayed your lordship to a dedication. I am bold to believe, fancies of this composure, have been nobly entertained, by the most knowing princes of the world: the ignorance,
that begets the change in this our age, it may become your lordship's example, to correct, me to lament; if so tame a passion, can possess a poet, and one, exalted with a hope to be received

closer.signed: Your lordship's humble servant, William D'avenant.

div.head: To my friend m. D'avenant, on his legitimate poem.
div.l: Even so the silly Midas judged of old
Twixt pan and great Apollo. As this bold
Herd, of his race, that th'untuned pipe admire,
And hear thy strains, as the dull ass the lyre.
What wonder then, if thou the lawful son
Of Phoebus, taste what was to him begun.
Hence, giddy fools; run to the noise they make
At paris-garden; or yourselves betake
To the new motion, the fine puppet plays,
And there adore. Commend the learned lays
That make a din about the streets, or else
Extol the jew's-trump, or the morris bells.
These, your great heads may manage. Only let
The wiser few, (Whose blessed ears have met
The harmony that all the muses make,
And from those heavenly sounds assurance take,
That thou singest the same tunes) admitted be
To thy seraphyck music, and set free
To entertain their souls in that high choir,
Which, not weak fools, but such as know, admire.

div.head: To my worthy friend, m. D'avenant, upon his excellent play, the just Italian.
div.l: I'll not misspend in praise, the narrow room
I borrow in this leaf; the garlands bloom
From thine own seeds, that crown each glorious page
Of thy triumphant work; the sullen age
Requires a satire. What star guides the soul
Of these our froward times, that dare control,
Yet dare not learn to judge? When didst thou fly
From hence, clear, candid ingenuity?
I have beheld, when perched on the smooth brow
Of a fair modest troop, thou didst allow
Applause to slighter works; but then the weak
Spectator, gave the knowing leave to speak.
Now noise prevails, and he is taxed for drought
Of wit, that with the cry, spends not his mouth.
Yet ask him, reason why he did not like;
Him, why he did; their ignorance will strike
Thy soul with scorn, and pity: mark the places
Provoke their smiles, frowns, or distorted faces,
When, they admire, nod, shake the head: they'll be
A scene of mirth, a double comedy.
But thy strong fancies (Raptures of the brain,
Dressed in poetic flames) they entertain
As a bold, impious reach; for they'll still slight
All that exceeds red bull, and cockpit flight.
These are the men in crowded heaps that throng
To that adulterate stage, where not a tongue
Of th'untuned kennel, can a line repeat
Of serious sense: but like lips, meet like meat;
Whilst the true brood of actors, that alone
Keep natural unstrained action in her throne
Behold their benches bare, though they rehearse
The terser Beaumont's or great Jonson's verse.
Repine not thou then, since this churlish fate
Rules not the stage alone; perhaps the state
Hath felt this rancour, where men great and good,
Have by the rabble been misunderstood.
So was thy play; whose clear, yet lofty strain,
Wise-men, that govern fate, shall entertain.

list.item: Florello a cast soldier his brother.

div.head: Scene the first.

sp.speaker: Mervolle.
sp.l: This puzzles my belief: the sickly moon
Hath not yet twice expired her usual ãâã
Since you did mingle souls, and can ãâã
That she so soon recoils from grace
Harmonious quiet of your bed?

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: My dear
Mervolle she is lost: as well may I
Collect the scattered winds into a bag,
Or from the watery surface scrape the gilt
Reflections of the sun, as bring her heart
Within the quiet list of wives that will
Obey and love.

sp.speaker: Mervolle.
sp.l: Can the Duke (Her uncle)
Give an encouragement to her revolt,
Maintain the females charter 'gainst the male?

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: Him, and his supreme title she still ãâã
To justify the glory of her birth,
And then recites the villages and wealth,
She brought to me for dowry, in parallel
With what I formerly possessed, she doth
affront my memory with storeys of
My lean and niggard fate, and urging then
Her vast supplies, doth challenge leave to call
Her pride and rigour just.

sp.speaker: Mervolle.
sp.l: This grief is of
Sad quality!

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: The heart hangs heavy on
The strings, when it alone contains the cause
And knowledge of its weight: for troubled winds
In their dispersion lose their strength; so griefs,
Whilst they're revealed, diminish from themselves.
But the calamities, that do perplex
The nuptial bed, are of a property
Recluse, and must be hidden even from friends:
For on such secrets fame doth feed with fierce,
And meager appetite âª and as swift fame
Doth travail with them, they increase. So much
Commerce I have with humane arts, that I
Can steep my gall in my own tears; and make
That salt which she intended bitter; show
Her crime to spring, not from poisoned malice,
But from the feminine mistakes of wit:
For modern courts now preach, wit doth reside
In ladies' subtle riots, and their pride.

div.stage: Enter Florello, Rossa, Molard: in soldierly mean habits.

sp.speaker: Mervolle.
sp.l: Behold your brother (Sir) whose safe return,
This morn I mentioned to your ear â

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: Thy growth
Hath so o'erreached my sight, that I'm estranged
To my best blood: and but, thy figure in
My heart I wear (By which my memory's
Informed) I should not know I had thee here â

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: I reckon this the chief delight I have
Received on earth. And (Sir) your love is of
Such sovereign quality, a little soon
will overcharge my sense. Give but a part
To me, the rest confer upon my friends â
Who, though in withered habits, do deserve,
Society with Kings: for never yet,
Did bolder soldiers listen to the drum.

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: Gentlemen, ye shall enrich my knowledge â

sp.speaker: Rossa:
sp.l: Noble signior, unprofitable love
Is all our wealth â

sp.speaker: Molard.
sp.l: But we'll contrive ourselves
For your best use. â

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: I've said, consider them
Within; their weeds are overgrown and cheap.

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: Brother ( howe'er wise fate may answer it)
Methinks , these your own robes are not o'th right
Tyrian die; nor hath the rich weight of your
Tall plume the ostrich robbed of both her wings.

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: Even thus (Sir) poor, and with small victory
Am I returned from our cast troops. Our pay
Rests in areres, and Pisa's lost: but you
(I hear) have found a jewel, that contains
All price and lustre; and you do wear it
In your bosom: (A noble wife) whose birth
And beauty, are alike unvalued as
Her dowry. This I encountered on
The lips of fame; and I made haste to share
In your success, and put your bounty to
The test.

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: Florello, I have lost my sleep.
Things differ much from the sincerity
Of their first growth: Alteza hath forgotten
Th'allegiance of a wife, she doth practise
How with her riot to impoverish states,
And by her lofty pride, to justify
The immortality of flesh: this theme
Is sad; but I will give you cause t'expect
The utmost strength and power of my relief.

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.p: You teach my feeble wants a confidence.

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: If you a while obscure yourself (For fear
Your poverty increase her scorn) you shall
Perform a rational request. Our young
Fair sister, is concealed for the same cause.

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: Your mention doth anticipate my love.
Is our fair sister well?

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: She doth enjoy
Rare beauty, and much health.

sp.speaker: Alta.
sp.p: You and your friends, move back, and be not seen.

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: Try signior Allidore, Antonio's son:
Utruvio, or the rich Pirracco.
Gritalin, or old Contarini of
Placentia â

sp.speaker: Niente.
sp.l: Madam, your husband hath
Protested 'gainst your credit, even to these.

sp.speaker: Alte.
sp.p: Slave, go force an answer more delightful.

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: Is't come to this?
I'll be a crooked spinster first, and with
My spittle and my flax procure my bread.

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: What is the cause my Princess thus delights
In frowns? Anger sits on her brow like age.

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: Hence, I see thee, and my eyes shrink into
My skull: the raven's not so ominous and black.

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: Yet urge the cause (My love) why your
Defiance is so violent and loud?

sp.speaker: Alte.
sp.l: A Millainois showed me today for sale,
Bright and spacious jewels; but in the dark,
Your pusill malice hath betrayed my faith,
With merchants. You have now my credit wrought
So low, and cheap; I cannot stand deposed
For th'trivial loan of forty thousand crowns.

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: I would survey a list of all your wants,
That I may so have power to hasten the
Redress: do you dislike your properties
Of house, your vestments, or service of your
Table; give but a name unto thy wish?

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.p: I would have my orchard â paved with agates.

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: O, and your garden walls raised high, t'hedge in
Paraquitoes, and th'rhetorical Daw?

sp.speaker: Altera.
sp.p: Thou hast a rude heart, and a blistered tongue!

sp.speaker: Charintha.
sp.l: Well, the first day of your conjunction sir,
I little thought you would have used her thus.

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: And I perceive a masculine itch beneath
Her left eye; she longs to taste man.

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: Come love,
Be gentle as thy bridal smiles: for by
Thyself I swear, my speech did purpose naught âª
To tempt thy spleen. Lend me thy melting hand!

sp.speaker: Alte.
sp.l: There â 'tis to reach back the heart I gave ye â

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: You spirits that secure the property
Of humane love, be still official here!
Why should we not for ever thus remain,
Incorporate, and conjoined. 'tis sympathy,
And love, that gives the world continuance
And life. Each species love preserves. 'tis love
That makes th'eternal wisdom thus forbear
The silly crimes of dull humanity:
And suffers us, like each delighted fly,
To play the trivial wantons in his eye.

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: You preach of love, but your obedience would
More pleasure me.

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: This argues thy revolt!
And is a stratagem against nature.
Thou wouldst usurp the charter of the male,
'Tis my confession, that thy dowry was vast
And opulent, and such as may support
Thy titles, and thy birth, with all the pride
and cunning of magnificence. Let my
Sincere phrase instruct thy heart. Reassume
The blushes of thy youth; with timorous
Modesty behave thy gesture and thy tongue,
And then, thou shalt stand up exemplary
To all triumphant courts: the envy of
The Eastern Queens: th'astrologers mistake,
Who shall direct their optics unto thee,
As to a new and unknown star.

sp.speaker: Alteza
sp.l: Sister! â

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: The small musicians of the air (Whom Queens
With mimic falconry do perch upon
Their fists) shall be thy food. Thy maids shall eat
Young pelicans, and squirrels hearts.

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: Thy beverage shall be prophetic, and
Divine; for thou shalt drink that sovereign dew,
That hangs upon the frighted lilies cheek,
And brewed with syrens tears, such as they shed
In real obsequies.

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: O bounteous sir! â

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: The soft entrail o'th Persian worm, th'ermine's
Pale fur, shall clothe thy limbs.

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: Those gums and spices which the Arabian bird,
Collects to make her tragic piles, shall be
Thy winter fuel âª

sp.speaker: Alta.
sp.l: Thou shalt have marmosets, and dwarfs, the male
And female too, to procreate in thy house;
That thy delights may ever be renewed.
Thy jewels shall increase, as if the loved
Indies were thy quarry. Th'almighty sun
Shall rise, and see a nobler day break from
Thy cabinet, then yet the illustrious East
Ere knew.

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.p: But how will you perform these hopes?

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: The miracle, and power, do both consist,
In my large wealth.

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.p: Death on my tribe! Your wealth?

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: This iteration
Scarce will delight, if it be negative.

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.p: Canst thou persist in such accursed schism?

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: Did you not then intend, when you endowed
Me with your wealth, that I should call it mine?

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: By heaven not I. I forfeited the love
O'th' great Duke (My uncle) to marry thee;
That wert a thing shrunk from thy fate, and lost
Unto the lips and eyes of men; but yet
In most assured hope, that thou wouldst prove,
An humble and obedient husband.

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: Thou'rt more impudent, than the basilisk,
Who stares i'th blessed face of man, until
He kill him with his eyes.

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: Hear Altamont!
For I will give solemnity unto
A vow, that shall for evermore, divide
Thee from my bed â

sp.speaker: Mervolle.
sp.l: Dear madam hold! Each sense
Of mine doth blush, that can perceive, your wild,
Rebellious wrath. Hath not the church named him
Your husband, and your lord?

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: M'opinions of
The church, I'll tell to'th conclave, not to you â

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: Is this the help, divinity gave man?
Snuff the moon, she burns dim. The spheres are now
Ill tuned, and aged nature backward reels.

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: Thy anger's vain. Here I do banish thee
My bed: and we will never more embrace.

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: I now divide my house:
This side is mine, with the dimensions that
dependence have on this square frame: for here
My family and I will rule. That side
You, and your meager ragged train possess.
Thou mayst henceforth my neighbour, but no more
My husband be. Charintha, come away â

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: I must pursue, lest she her anger make
Too loud, so we invite the public scorn.

sp.speaker: Mervolle.
sp.l: Is not thy brother's wife a pure tame hen?
How dost thou like her noise?

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: Were she but mine,
I'd teach her keep a noise too after death.

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: I'd strip her skin o'er her ears and
Make a drum on't.

sp.speaker: Rossa.
sp.p: She was born in a storm!

sp.speaker: Molard.
sp.p: And begot sure with the boatswain's whistle.

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: Mervolle, you have named Charintha,
As a precious virgin, of nature most
Remiss, a quiet tongue, and such a heart,
As might become an able sacrifice,
T'expiate the whole world?

sp.speaker: Mervolle.
sp.l: This I esteemed
My justice on her merits, but it seems
Her sister's documents o'er rule her now.
Her dowry is of ample rate, and may
Deserve the chief of our Italian youth.

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.p: What's Dandalo, that sues to her for love?

sp.speaker: Mervolle.
sp.l: Dandalo, the count of Milan? A thing
Composed of spicery and starch! Nature
Contrived him in her sleep. If's ignorance
Might answer for his sins; he would account
Amongst his wealth, the land he has in heaven.

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.p: I heard you say, she never saw him yet.

sp.speaker: Mervolle.
sp.l: Never sir: he woos her by his letters.
She desiring a personal survey
Ere prosecution of the suit, he sent
her word, he'd make's address by stealth; but we
Expect him not ere th'birth of the next moon.

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: Will his arrival be so long delayed? â
Brother! â how thrives your patience o'er your wife?

sp.speaker: Alta.
sp.l: Some philosophic hope remains: the storm
Can't last, because 'tis still more violent.
Sh'ath ta'en caroche for the palace, and means
Straight to disgrace me to the Duke
By her complaints.

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: Florello, I desire thou'lt not appear
Before her eye, until thy habit's changed.
My present power sums but a thousand crowns,
Which I have brought, and prostrate to thy use â

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: Sir it is fit your blessings were increased;
And that your wife had read your worth.

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: My art betrays my hopes, or I have found
A remedy to cure her pride: your help
Mervolle, I must crave, and with swift speed:

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: Rossa, Molard, (Friends to my soul and brain)
Advance your subtle eyes! The sovereign mine
Behold, that makes the solemn patriarch dance,
And the anointed King to skip, as doth
His limber dwarf.

sp.speaker: Molard
sp.p: Shall we be tender natured, and divide?

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: This is the portion will procure us all
High dignity and place. Rossa, you must
Find cause to number these â go, ransom out
Our captive weeds, and the rich habit I
From Pisa brought: whilst you (Mollard) with the
Assistance of these few â procure us fit
Materials to adorn, and put in bright
Aspect our corpse. Inquire for pearls: stones of
The cunningest soil, we'll like them, and disburse.

sp.speaker: Rossa.
sp.l: Is there some aged vessel now asleep
In the dock, that will pay for her calking?

sp.speaker: Molard.
sp.p: Florello, must we stop the public leaks?

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: Ere long we shall be great, be able to
Advance with smiles, and with our frowns destroy.
You Rossa, I'll create a magistrate.
Go practise the austere cough. Pale dilinquents
Thou shalt learn to jeer, and to sleep o'er men
Condemned.

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: Thou (My molard) shalt rule in villages,
Grow popular, and mistake the laws. Thou shalt
Delight i'th calendar: the rubric days
Thou shalt observe, and then destroy thy beef.
Whilst thy dull earthy tenants feed until
They smell.

sp.speaker: Molard.
sp.l: My lancepresado then shall sop
His crust in cider and in wine!

sp.speaker: Rossa âª
sp.l: And my
Dread corporal shall sin no more for leeks,
His girdle and his socks he shall unpawn.

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: The solitary hostess shall no more
Boil the carrion meat that she must trust,
In her own tears; nor with a requiem bring
The service up, as if it were the haunch
Of her dead husband.

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: The geographic captain shall no more
Study the town map, that's dark walks may be
Contrived through slender allies and through lanes,
To scape his hungry creditors abroad.

sp.speaker: Rossa.
sp.l: Thy province is Chaldea, thy father
Was a rabbi!

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: These are the victories of wit: by wit
We must achieve our hopes; which to refine
And purify, with paces doubled let's
descend a marble vault, there taste the rich
Legitimate blood of the mighty grape.
'Tis precious as the milk of Queens; such as
Would teach dull Saturn laugh. It magnifies
The heart, and makes the agile spirits dance,
It drowns all thoughts adulterate and sad;
Inspires the prophet, makes the poet glad.

div.head: Scene the first.

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: I have received a mandate from the Duke,
That will (I fear) increase her insolence.
Like an old tyrant he bestows his threats;
As if his anger did obey his will,
Not justice, nor the laws.

sp.speaker: Mervolle.
sp.l: Does your wife know
This preparation you have made to cure
Her haughtiness?

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: All is discovered to
Her ear: the news hath taught her boil her heart
In her own blood. She now weeps vinegar;
Boasts of revenge, as if the thunder were
Her own.

sp.speaker: Mervolle.
sp.l: 'Twere fit your pretty agent here,
Received instructions how to shape her garb
And port, just as th'imployment doth require.

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: Her knowledge is already satisfied.
Alteza's threats shall only move her scorn.

sp.speaker: Scoperta.
sp.l: I will perform my best in your behalf âª
But I do fear I am not valiant sir. Enter Niente.

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: O, you! that call your sins your duty, that
obey your lady's riots out o'zeal! â

sp.speaker: Niente.
sp.l: Signior! â

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: Her honour's spittle you preserve
As a restorative for your salt itch

sp.speaker: Niente.
sp.l: I beseech ye â

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: You thread in bracelets too,
The pearls that drop from her authentic nose.

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: To cleave you from the scalp
Unto the twist: to make nine skittles of
Your bones, and wind your heartstrings about my thumb â

sp.speaker: Niente.
sp.l: O mercy sir! So rotten are my limbs
That when you stretch your cheeks and blow on me,
I straight am scattered into sand â

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: Coward!
Creep straight into my hourglass then, and there
Eternally distinguish fatal time âEnter Alteza.

sp.speaker: Alteza ..
sp.p: What slave disturbs the quiet of my ear?

sp.speaker: Niente.
sp.l: Ne'er look sir! I serve my lady; and I
Do scorn to yield â

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: D'ye bristle porcupine? â

sp.speaker: Niente.
sp.l: Take heed! â I have the malady of France â

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: Stay Altamont! withdraw thy violence!
If thou disorder'st but a hair, that doth
Belong to th'eyebrow of my meanest groom,
I will proclaim my superiority
And rule i'th' streets.

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: Insult beneath thy own low roof! This part
O'th' house doth call me sovereign

div.stage: She spies Scoperta, and comes near her.

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: Is that the piece you have so magnified,
She you boast of for your pastime royal?

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: She clips the grey and shivered wings of time
To make him slow; that our embraces like
succeeding minutes then, may add unto
Their length. Let me engender on thy lips â

sp.speaker: Scoperta.
sp.l: So our progeny may still be kisses â

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: A meek and gentle heat, whilst thus we bill
We imitate the sober lust of doves â

sp.speaker: Scoperta.
sp.l: That kiss (Sir) was so powerful and moist,
That you have robbed my lips of all their wealth!

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: Take back thy wealth again! â

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: Are ye so hot? â

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: Thy lips are thin and lank (Alteza) as
The lids that close thine eyes. Hers gently swell
Like Eastern fruit, and are more soft than is
The fleecy air that clothes the infant morn.

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: Pray a word! Is there in this pageantry
Ought like to truth? Discover your intent!

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: I'll make my anger equal unto thine,
And my revenge above them both. This bright
Auspicious maid shall govern in my bed.
She is my concubine: the off spring of
Her womb shall triumph here, maugre thy sight:
Whilst envy does consume thy flesh until
Thy body lighter grow then thy loose mind.

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.p: How well my stars behave their influence?

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: Mervolle, go! my mistress guide unto
Those lodgings that o'erview the garden mount.

sp.speaker: Scoperta.
sp.l: If you retard your presence whilst the sun
(In's race) fill up one hour, you'll find before
Your next review, that grief hath made me old,
And I shall look more like a matron than
A bride; so much your absence mortifies.

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: Thou art to every sense I have, a spell.
Conduct her straight (Mervolle) to some throne!

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: Then are the vows, the ecclesiastic rites
With which the zealous priest obliged us to
Peculiar heat, to abstinence from change,
And various love, quite cancelled by your lust?

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: Go, thou art as light as feathers, or the air,
Were but an atom individual placed
With thee in balance even, 'twould hoist thee up
To th'clouds.

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: Thy breath is fulsome as that steam
Which toads when they engender vaporate.

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: Alteza, bath in penitential tears
Thy leprous heart, or when the elements
Are mixed and the sad day arrives, that dooms
The world unto eternity of joy,
Or pain, thou shalt (Like to a glimmering lamp)
Be hung upon the sooty walls of hell.

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: I smile at thee, and thy thin arts; like to
Some homely village Levite, thou dost preach
Of terrors strange, to keep dull faith in awe:
I pray stay; I am not angry sir.

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: I practised all this while how t'endanger
Your spleen (Sir) not my own âª which if my powers
Prove just, I shall, perform ere long.
Niente, send the party in âExit Niente.

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.p: A slow device (Sir) but o'my own brain.

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: A keen guest, invited here â

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.p: To taste â your wives gammons.

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.p: Bold slave! be in thy speech more evident.

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.p: I am come to get your children for you.

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: D'ye want a clearer paraphrase? He is
My servant sir, my stallion if I please.
A courtly implement, and much in use
among ladies of my growth and title.

sp.speaker: Alta.
sp.l: O my cold blood! My patience will be wrought
So low, that I shall learn t'milk a heifer.

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: Since I'm so aptly furnished with delight,
Your concubine may fearless walk about
The house, and share the wholesome sun in peace.

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: Thy tongue I do neglect: but you (Sir) shall
Ere long complain of your mortality:
The minutes you must waste on earth are few.

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: This I consider sir, and therefore make
Such haste to mingle with your wife; that the
Kind world may have some issue from my loins.

sp.speaker: Alta.
sp.l: If this prove true, let babes piss out my eyes â

div.stage: He draws his sword, Sciolto his, Alteza her stilleto.

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: Hold Altamont, or else I wound thy heart â

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: If you advance one inch beyond that rush
I'll amble through the streets, and blow your dirge
With the great horn that grows upon your brow.

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: If there be gall in heaven, the general bag
Is opened, and it falls in showers!

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: 'Slight sir;
I come t'ease the labour of your body;
And you want courtship to return me thanks.

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: But what hereafter I
Perform, shall be for your good lady's sake,
And not for yours.

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: Pray (Sir) let's interchange
A little breath: withal (If you consent)
We'll put our swords to a more quiet use â

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: Now sir, you pour sweet cassia in my broth.
My blood affects to skirmish more
With ladies then with men. What would you speak?

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: My true opinion sir concerning you.
I know you do but counterfeit this lust,
This lawless heat. You purpose not t'abuse
The charter of my bed,

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: I read it in your noble feature and
Your looks. You have religion in your shape.
And can it be, you should so soon commit a crime
So much unwholesome to the angel's sight?
Let me now make a forfeiture of eyes,
If ever I beheld a man that's more obliged
To nature for his limbs: a carnal frame
So full of equal strength I never saw.

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: The better shaped I am (Sir) the more cause
You'll find, to love the issue I shall get
Upon your wife.

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: Do not belie thy own
True merits and comport! Th'adulterate fire
Did ne'er inflame thy sober heart, I know
Thou scornest to do't.

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: Not I believe it sir!
Sir I will do't. Is your lady fruitful?
I would be loath t'lose my labour on her?

div.stage: He draws, and they as before.

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: Fling a danger from
Thy arm, I'll summon straight (With trumpet and
With drum) the world to hear thy infamy â

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: O fie! You an Italian sir, and thus
Behave the knowledge of disgrace with loud
And popular dislike?

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: Nay it becomes
You finely, does it not?

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: You think because
You're cursed, we'll allow you short horns: I'll graft
Upon your head a pair so tall, they shall
Go near to prick the very planet (Sir)
Thet ruled at your nativity.

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: Signior, go! take down a cushion, and pray âª
You cannot choose but know the frailty of
the times: the surfeits of the womb, and how
Great ladies do relieve their appetites.
Your own confession of my parts commends
Your wife in her sage choice. There be that sin
With feeble ushers and the withered dwarf.

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.p: He wants a judgement to consider this.

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: I merit better looks sir, that must thrash
All night for ye, and without wages sir!

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: Dead as a monument! Let us leave him! â

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: Had he the devil for's physician chose,
He could ne'er have come by the like cordial. â

sp.speaker: Alta.
sp.l: You swelling mountains (That o'erview the earth)
Fall now, make me eternally unseen!
Philosophy contract thy meek sage brow:
Let patience be no more thy saint. As soon
Give medicines to the dead, teach statues how
To walk, and angry winds to sleep i'th North.
As soon bid empty lions play with kids;
And to the shaggy Scythian say, go weep
As virgins do, when they their loves inter:
The blind and shuffled elements that first
In chaos strove, were not so opposite
As this religious frost unto my heat.
Patience, thou art more fond than teeming wives,
Tamer than sheep! Divinity which calls
Our anger sin, and courage pride, hath sent
This silly cherubin on earth, Patience,
(The coward's sword) which only doth disarm
Dull sleep, that neither can nor would do harm. Exit.

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: Florence knows me well: I'm called Sciolto,

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: I needs must sing my usher's praise: he made
A most discreet election of a man.

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: Your mercy and your kindness (Lady) thus
advance my shape; your pleasure was I should
Despise your husband's frowns, and I behaved
Myself with terror masculine: but now
We are peculiar and reserved, I know
Humility, a soft and quiet garb;
A distance that shall well become the state
So eminent and rich a beauty claims.

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: Sir, that we do expect, and than you shall
O'er take our noble sense, with newer love.
Our husband is a trifle, such as can
No way disturb your peace or safety here.

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: Madam, store me with arms and weapons to
Resist his personal assault, and I
Shall need no more protection than myself.

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: Active and bold! Niente thou hast made
A choice out-parallels the world.

sp.speaker: Niente.
sp.l: Madam,
See his horse veins: they're large as conduit pipes;
His sinews are like cables.

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: 'Las! not mine!
'Tis true, that if I like my opposite,
I have a trick to give an easy fall,
And stand to't stiffly too when I ha'done â

sp.speaker: Niente.
sp.l: I will assure your ladyship, the bawds
Give him good report.

sp.speaker: Niente.
sp.p: He's great with ladies of all ages, all degrees.

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.p: Excuse me sir, they're great by me!

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.p: Madam â they are all with-child!

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.p: How signior? Is your appetite so strong?

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: Blame the humorous planets that o'errule
The blood. Ere yet this present month expires;
(Let's see â I,!) Some three and forty ladies
(Or there about) will quicken with male twins.

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: So wise fame sings.
I will make bold to gather my first fruits âGoes to kiss her.

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: Stay my pregnant signior! Our love is not
Yet ripe: there is a larger distance too
Belongs unto our lips.

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: I am too proud to have my favours soon
And easily conferred. Such smiles are cheap.
I mean to procreate by prescription sir,
Make my lust as physical as my meals.

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: Death, I'm suitor unto Gallens widow!
Madam, I know it not becomes the high
Demeanour of your birth to dance (Just like
A kid) to th'music of each wind that blows.
Ere you admit of dalliance I should use
Some industry of tongue, and flexure of
The pliant joints, to court and woo consent.

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: And can your rudeness covet then where your
Safe wit and knowledge warns your abstinence?

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: Only a little t'recreate the chine â

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: Keep back, if you'll continue life. When I
Am pleased to be delighted sir, I can
Command the function of your limbs.
Charintha within.madam!

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: Sister, I come. Throw him to his chamber â

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: Hast no good book, whose comfortable use
May fill th'expense of time?

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: Any o'th Moderns. Rabelais i'th praise of
Midwives. Aretine on copulation.
Or th'odes of Theophile unto his whore.

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: My usher in my closet can appoint
Your choice of these.

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: Think on the frailty of
The flesh; and be not long unmerciful â
Charintha within.sister! Madam!

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.p: Away; I come, I come. Exeunt Niente, Sciolto:

sp.speaker: Charintha.
sp.p: The Milan count (My suitor) is arrived.

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: Signior Dandolo! Why 'tis yet a month
Ere he should meet your expectation here.

sp.speaker: Besognia.
sp.l: 'Tis he madam, and such a he as must
Be only likened to himself.

sp.speaker: Charintha.
sp.l: More rich,
And gaudy than the East. So liberal too,
That you would think he natures steward were.
He gives amongst my slaves, as if unto
Ambassadors he did cast donatives.

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: Milk him (My Charintha) oft I have preached
Unto thine ear a sovereignty o'er man.
Take all he gives, it's princely fashion now.
Could but thy acceptation beggar him,
Thy little wit were ever magnified.

sp.speaker: Charintha.
sp.l: You know I am o'th' wits, I have been sworn
To beggar suitors, and jeer my husband.

div.stage: Enter Florello in rich habit. Rossa, Molard, shifted like his servants.

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.p: Which is the lady that I come to woo?

sp.speaker: Charintha.
sp.l: My name's Charintha â

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: Present me thy lips!
I say advance â

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: You are not understood â

div.stage: He kisses Charintha, then gives her a jewel.

sp.speaker: Charintha.
sp.l: My lord, I scarcely own desert enough
T'entice this jewel from your cabinet.

sp.speaker: Florel.
sp.l: A stone, a stone! the thing grows, I've enough â

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: So free? I am Charintha's sister sir â

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: It may be so. A fine house, fine town too!
Were Florence mine, I would not give it for
The best winter seat my father left me.

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: 'Tis sir, th'ambition of my love, that you
Would know me for Charintha's sister! â

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.p: I must know her for Charintha's sister.

sp.speaker: Charintha.
sp.l: Is there no trick in ceremony sir,
To give your memory a better hint?

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: Kiss none but thee! A device i'th' blood! but
Princes have one toy or other still, t'make
Their descent known. â there, a diamond that,
And that a ruby. âGives to Alteza.

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: They're none of mine. I have enough, wear 'em â

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: Your lordship binds my great acknowledgement.
I'th leisure of a wink, he'll give away
An empire.

sp.speaker: Besognia.
sp.l: I'm Charintha's woman sir â

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: Who can help it? Mistress, wilt thou not bid
My servants welcome? They're rich choughs, they've store
Of villages, and ploughed earth.

sp.speaker: Charintha.
sp.l: Their judgement is
So kind (Sir) as to know they may command
The house.

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: This is my parasite, and this my pimp.
I've a fool, a dwarf too at home. I made
My jaunt too early by a month, or else
My train had been enlarged.

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: They're rarely fixed,
If they import as much as you denominate.

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: I keep my parasite to cure the dull
Melancholy of state. He does admire
My wit and beard. He says I cannot sin.
Prince's would still be sad out for such worms.

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.p: But how (Sir) does your pimp adhere to use?

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: He is as pertinent to lords as lust.
My fool I keep to laugh at me. My dwarf
Is for my wife. I do intend she shall
Affect the court, and then she'll quickly learn.
To make the toy useful.

sp.speaker: Charintha.
sp.l: My lord, be pleased
To walk, and use th'advantage of the air.

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: I've instruments distinct, that take a charge
O'th several quarters of my frame, my dwarf
Doth dress me up unto the knees, and when
His stature leaves his reach, young virgins then
(Th'issue of decayed barons) do begin
And govern to the navel. Whilst onwards
Barbers, painters, and parasites are used.

sp.speaker: Charin.
sp.l: But will your lordship walk and see the spring?
We have a garden where it ever dwells.

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.p: And shall we be delighted and entranced?

sp.speaker: Charintha.
sp.l: We'll sacrifice the utmost of our wealth
And love, t'express your welcome sir.

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: Wilt i' faith.
There's a sapphire chain: tie thy monkey in't â
Take it; for by this hand I am in haste
And cannot offer twice.

sp.speaker: Besognia.
sp.l: If you should chance
(My honoured lord) to drop those trifles here,
I would be mannerly, and reach 'em up.

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: I will give thee a bushel of seed-pearl
To embroider thy petticoat.

sp.speaker: Charintha.
sp.l: This way â

sp.speaker: Rossa.
sp.l: Your lordship hath forgotten to leave notice for
Those princes in disguise that shall by chance
Demand ye at the gate.

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: A leash of German Dukes that walk in Rugge.
I should consult with 'em 'bout subversion
Of a state or two; but I'm not yet at
Leisure.

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.p: My lord, they shall be answered so.

sp.speaker: Rossa.
sp.p: Your hypocrisy wants a little art.

sp.speaker: Molard.
sp.p: Your bounty will impoverish us too soon.

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: Ye both do lie, I weave my cunning close.
Fortune, redeem the credit of thy eyes.
Thou wilt (If thou art partial now and kind)
But wink on me, though to the world thou'rt blind.

div.head: Scene the first.
div.stage: Enter Altamont, Mervolle. Sciolto at the other door.

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: This is the truth, therefore consider now
My fate. Ha! Sciolto!

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: 'Tis sciolto, the brute adulterer,
He whom I lately mentioned in my speech.
A slave more salt than is the Baltic ware,
More hot than hell, a satire or a goat.

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: And shall be still so (Sir) unless your wife
Dismiss her pride, and vouchsafe to cool me.

sp.speaker: Alta.
sp.l: Devils and death, I'm murdered through the ear â

div.stage: He draws, Sciolto pulls forth a case of pistols,

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: Take discipline awhile, know if there be
A boisterous motion used, I have for each
Of you a round cinnamon plum, and they
Shall enter your nice stomachs the wrong way â

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: Though thou wert hardy as the lion's race;
And armed with all th'artillery on earth,
I durst assault thee as I am; but so
I cannot satisfy revenge.

sp.speaker: Mervolle.
sp.l: Sciolto, now my memory begins
To know you better: for your riots bold
And loud demeanour in this city hath
Been long observed. I wonder much y'emply
Your precious minutes in a course so vile.

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: What, as to copulate and increase kind?
It has been a vocation ever since
The sun spied man thus crawling on the earth â

sp.speaker: Mervolle.
sp.l: But what excuse canst thou in honour urge,
For wearing such advantageous defence,
Against his just and single violence?

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.p: I have an odd humour, not to be killed.

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: O Alteza, had but my name been hid
Beneath some fold in the voluminous
Dark book of fate, I might have missed of my
Creation then, so I should ne'er have seen
Thy face.

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: My curses (Sir) have cause t'assault
Her more than yours: for she has starved me here
With want of natural delight. My free
Large growth and tincture of my hair denote,
My constitution cannot suffer me,
To wear a surplice, or proceed eunuch.
Though I should bathe and swim in julips sir,
I've still unruly heat about my chine.

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: A salamander that doth feed and clothe
Itself with flame, was thy progenitor.

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: Have I not equal reason to complain?
In three hours not so much as a dry kiss.
Th'old amorous deacon that embraced his cow
Was not so destitute.

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: A negro might be useful now, although
She'd but one eye, and that fixed on her heel.

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: I'll strew upon thy food the teeth of snakes,

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: Signior, presume no more upon a fond
Easy nature. I have been abstinent
Too long. Haste, and with pliant steps present
Your wife; or else I'll assure ye you shall seek
Some other man to cuckold ye for me.

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: I'll shoot
Thy heart with needles, small as splinters of
a hair that thou mayst die, and yet not know
That thou art killed.

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: I thank ye (Signior) but
We Florentines do sleep like leverets,
With our eyes open: howe'er , I could vouchsafe
To shoot you now, and prevent your kindness. â

sp.speaker: Mervolle.
sp.l: Sciolto, hold. If either charge do miss,
He that survives, shall grind thy marble heart,
Between his teeth â

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: I meant not to give fire.
There is a trick of gravity i'th state
Called law. Besides, you dead, the children which
I chance to get upon your buxom wife,
I should go near to keep at my own charge.

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.p: Africa breeds no monster like to thee.

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: I'll to my chamber now, and fortify
There, I remain (During the pleasure of
Your wife) your tenant (Signior) in fee tail. âExit.

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: It is a cunning, and promiscuous slave.
This story of Alteza's abstinence,
He doth but counterfeit, to gull my sight.

sp.speaker: Mervolle.
sp.l: Had the devil himself crept into flesh,
And undertook this service to your wife,
She had possessed, the weaker instrument.
He hath in is veins, a most intemperate blood
His valour's so renowned, that all the smooth,
The curled, and silken nobles of the town,
Do homage to his sword; and by such acts
As these, he glorifies his truant youth.

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: Thy faith was jealous, I seduced thy ear
To share untruths: but now, thou knowest too much.

sp.speaker: Mervolle.
sp.l: Was my suspect of fame, and dispersement
Of your deep wrong, that manacled till now,
Your hands. My temperate lectures cease. Obey
Revenge, and I will follow it, until
My wealth, and life, are forfeited to law.

sp.speaker: Alta.
sp.l: Ha! wilt thou? O my quickened heart (Entombed
before within my breast) wilt thou? This, this
Then is the direful night, wherein I'll give
A strict and cruel justice to revenge.

sp.speaker: Mervolle.
sp.l: This then is the night, wherein my bold love
Shall merit me th'eternal name of friend.

sp.speaker: Alt.
sp.l: Come swear, swear now (On this victorious sword)
Thou wilt obey th'injunctions of my wrath,
And yet in personal act, not move, but when
My will appoints a mixture of thy strength.

sp.speaker: Mervolle.
sp.l: My choice religion, and the honours of my blood,
I here do pawn to ratify the vow â

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: Now work my injured spirits, till you make
Dull sorrow rise in nimble flame. Anger,
Is blood, powered, and perplexed into a froth,
But malice is, the wisdom of our wrath. Exeunt.

div.stage: Ent. Florello, Charintha, Alteza, Rossa, Molard.

sp.speaker: Charintha.
sp.p: Your lordship's letters were of a prompt style!

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: This orient rope is yours, and you must wear't;
I sicken else, and grow a villager
In Elysium!

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: Take it. Afflict me fame, if ere I knew
His parallel; he woos at nero's rate. Enter Besognia.

sp.speaker: Besognia.
sp.l: Madam, there's a new Dandolo, a new
Count, lighted at the gate, and craves entrance.

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: That's rare i'faith; have I a shadow walks
Without leave o'the sun?

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: Did not Mervolle say, 'twould be a month,
Ere he arrived?

sp.speaker: Rossa.
sp.p: Be bold and meet your chance

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: Stand firm, and stiffly on your sinews then,
Avouch me still, for the true Dandolo.

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: Charintha, 'tis some stratagem; but if
He jewels bring, and in a hand as large,
And open as yond easy snipes, thou hast
Ill luck if thou constrain him not to loss.

sp.speaker: CharinthaÂ·
sp.l: I'll smile no longer than these rich sparkles
Shine in my eyes. Enter Dandolo.

sp.speaker: Dandolo.
sp.l: The lady that is named
Charintha here, must be revealed; for I'd
Exalt her lips, and make 'em known to mine.

sp.speaker: Flo:
sp.l: 'Slight, this is the great cham. Hark ye, signior â

sp.speaker: Charintha.
sp.p: My lord, I pray afford him leave to speak.

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.p: What, is that saucy groom? Does he sell eggs?

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: I'll show ye my trade; a poor swordman, I â

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: Sir you destroy the quiet of my house:
He shall have safety here, and leave to speak.

sp.speaker: Charintha.
sp.p: I'm called Charintha sir; proceed to speech.

sp.speaker: Dandolo.
sp.l: I'll first do special grace unto your lip â
My pen hath wooed you oft; but now by stealth
Thus single I'm arrived, a moon before
The time I did prefix.

sp.speaker: Dandolo.
sp.l: Was winter when I specified the date
Of my approach, and then my blood was cold;
But now the spring is come, things would couple.
These (Lady) are very secular pearl â

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: Ay sir, and in such toys, she much delights:
Although her modesty be loath, to make
Her fancies known. Would you had brought some few
To match 'em.

sp.speaker: Charintha.
sp.p: I rejoice in all the works of nature!

sp.speaker: Dandolo.
sp.p: That I did ill, to leave my pearls behind.

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: Sister this hulk, is neither rigged, nor fraught,

sp.speaker: Charintha.
sp.p: I'll have no more of him, he is too costive.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Sir a word. Methinks you look, like raw pork.

sp.speaker: Dandolo.
sp.p: Has not this house the privilege of peace?

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: Ladies, this impostor steals my titles,
And my name, I ask leave, to punish him.

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.p: We'll not protect his crimes, use your justice.

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: Unless you are an ostrich, sir, and can
Digest steel, cool your lungs, and calmly wait
Th'inquiry I shall urge.

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: Molard, reveal how long thou hast been pimp,
To the family of the Dandolos?

sp.speaker: Molard.
sp.l: About some thirty years (Sir.) I've procured
Both time and place, for your good father's game,
Ere since he was capable of woman.

sp.speaker: Rossa.
sp.p: He used the trade (Sir) in his infancy.

sp.speaker: Molard.
sp.l: I scare could walk, when I began't: the first
I brought him was my nurse.

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: Canst point, at ought
He did some two and twenty years ago?

sp.speaker: Molard.
sp.l: Distinctly sir. I know that gentleman,
He was got, on a tripewife of Lucca.

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.p: O th'action of my father's loins!

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: I'm an old jew at genealogies.
This fellow's descent I know now, and where
He took is creation too. By chance thus have
I met forty of my father's bastards.
They're poor, and put me oft to charge. Brother,
Welcome. â Rossa, give him a quardecus.

sp.speaker: Dandolo.
sp.p: Bid Kings wind silk, and prince's measure oats.

sp.speaker: Charin.
sp.l: Your train of parasite, pimp, fool and dwarf,
Speak you at first, to be the true young lord.

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: Yet th'other has some marks, that do belong
Unto a count, o'th last edition too:

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: He should be a Venetian,
By th' wit, and policy of his courage.

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.p: Beauties, were your hands clean, they should be kilâ ãâã.

sp.speaker: Dandolo.
sp.l: Sir, â you shall know,
No man ere got me, but my own father. Exit.

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: Besognia speak in my behalf; I'll give
Thee a pearl then, big as a pompion.

sp.speaker: Besognia.
sp.l: Which, when your lordship does, I'll return ye
A pointed diamond, big as a steeple.

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: Yon thrifty counterfeit, has much perplexed
Your servant's wit.

sp.speaker: Charintha.
sp.p: My lord. Let's in, and jeer.

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: Slow method fools obey. To th' stars advance
His head, who thus resists the power of chance. Ex. omnes.

sp.speaker: Scoperta.
sp.l: Like to my genius he doth move about
The house. Our souls are surely near allied â

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: Calls he her, his concubine? By this hand
There's not a prince in all the East, has such
Another. This Altamont still gripes 'em
In the flank; he knows to choose his cattle.
Be thou pleased, oh young and wholesome lady!

sp.speaker: Scoperta.
sp.l: The garden (Signior) doth contain more walks,
As pensative in shade as this. I do
Beseech you, change your path, and leave me here.

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: The fumes of spicery? you must not now â

sp.speaker: Mervolle.
sp.l: My vows have promised you the ample truth
Of my intelligence. Behold, whom there,
Sciolto keeps in amorous whisper.

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: Ha, Scoperta! Libidinous girl, what makes
She with that horse?

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: No, let 'em knit and generate; my words
Shall never penetrate her ear until
I am revenged for what my eyes have seen.

sp.speaker: Mervolle.
sp.p: There is a general tainture in the sex.

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: She is proscribed, I've filled her in the list
With those that taste tonight a bitter fate.
Away, away. This object ruins all
My faculties. Exeunt from above.

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: I sigh my first salute
Was so intemperately performed. But o!
The justice of my stars! My love is now
Revenged upon my lust. With pure chaste flame
I court the mistress unto Altamont;
One here reserved for sinful use. Stay, stay! â

sp.speaker: Scoperta.
sp.l: If I am seen, my life is forfeited â

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: Hast thou not heard my vows, whose violence
And number well might satisfy suspect
In wayward Kings.

sp.speaker: Scoperta.
sp.l: How dare I traffic thus
For love with thee: when thy accounts with heaven
Are yet not cleared that lust betrayed thee to?

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: With what advice of modesty canst thou
Accuse my blood; when in this mansion thou'rt
Contained for the like sin?

sp.speaker: Scoperta.
sp.l: Were I well known
Unto the quality of thy new love,
I would reveal myself, and take from thy
Belief the false opinion of my guilt.

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: If ere I practise impious heat again,
Some long armed fiend that in the centre dwells
Reach at my foot, and pull me into flames.

sp.speaker: Scoperta.
sp.l: Bear witness immortality and truth
That I'm official here but by pretence,
My veins are cold and chaste as Northern snow.

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.p: Thy name, and then my doubts I will forsake?

sp.speaker: Scoperta.
sp.l: Scoperta is my name. I sister am
To Altamont; not mistress of his lust.

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: O dire affinity! my love is now
Allied unto my hate. Yet Altamont
Near merited my wrath. It is the wit
The policy of sin, to hate those men
We have abused. When first I spied the grace
And lustre of thy shape; methought I loved,
And my sick heart informed me love was good:

sp.speaker: Scoperta.
sp.l: And you when I beheld, I said to heaven,
Oh make but his immortal part like to
The garment nature clothes it in, and he'll
Remain a type, from whom shall be derived
The prophets, and the Kings that rule the earth.

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: Her beauties so increase; that they do make
My comprehension poor.

sp.speaker: Scoperta.
sp.l: I should have used
More leisure and nice art, when I did give
My love away.

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: O stay, until my vows
Afford a larger warrant of my faith â

sp.speaker: Scoperta:
sp.l: Our new society must not be seen.
But if thy love be free from carnal arts,
(Such as the curled youth of Italy
Do use) make me thy sudden stealth âª early,
(Ere the succeeding sun arrive i'th' east)
Appear beneath my casements view, and I
Will follow thee along the spacious world.

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: Go noble maid, wert thou divided from
My reach, by sheets of elemental fire,
By streams of recking blood, by purple mists
(Which cannons in their acclamation breath)
Or winds (When met to blow each other from
The earth) yet I would pull thee to my heart.
False lust, I take of thee eternal leave â

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: Convey those odours thither, and disperse
The costly smoke, about the room.

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: Place soft and easy fingered lutes, behind
The arras; voices feminine and young.
And spread the couch, with the green Persian quilt.

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: I feel a slothful grudging in my veins,
And therefore mean to solace with a male.
Brush thy beard, and follow me. â

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: Now am I
As rascally a sinner, as ever.

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.p: Is not thy blood well? Kiss me sciolto.

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.p: Shall we be wrapped in curlings intricate?

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: We'll have our artificial heats, and with our own
Panting cool us to new, and younger strength.

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: And shall we between two shady poplars hang
I'th indian-net, whose slippery closures may
Entangle us so fast, we ne'er shall be
Untied again âª

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.p: We'll grow as in one skin.

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: Yes, much! Not an inch. â

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: And shall my action more. It mightiness
And state, taught me to fast from flesh; and now,
I am well pleased to make't perpetual lent.

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.p: I like this well. My male is witty grown.

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: Go, kneel to your husband, and beg from him
Lawful recreation: myself intend
To purchase a few beads, and turn votary.
She'll ne'er move hence, till I've enraged her spleen.

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.p: What motive (Sir) persuades ye, use me thus?

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.p: Why â ye are not handsome.

sp.speaker: Scio.
sp.l: Question your glass! Your face was carved â out of
A blue cabbage; and 'tis contracted now
To one, oblique wrinkle.

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: Thy aged skull in stead of hair
O'ergrown with moss, and looks as if t'had been,
A thousand years entombed.

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: Thy solitary teeth, in distance stand
Like the decayed arches of a bridge.

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: Wilt not yet go?
Thy fingers are all crooked, like the talons
Of a Griffon. Thou walkst on cloven-feet.

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: Thy bones are piled across âª
Much like the sticks on a conjurer's fire.

sp.speaker: Alte.
sp.l: Are my grooms dead? what hoa! I'll impound ye. â

div.stage: Sciolto pulls out a case of pistols.

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: It must not be. For with these two (Of which
I mean to rob your armoury) there shall
Be passage forced broad enough for a teem
Of Southern elephants. Farewell oyster! âExit.

sp.speaker: Alte.
sp.l: Where are my grooms, my slaves? injurious wolf.
Bark at my precious feature, and thus strew
My beauty o'er, with infamy and dust?
Strike my green youth, with epithets of age?
My Altamont ne'er used me thus. He oft
Compared me to the stars, m'eyes to Eastern light,
When day smiles at her birth. O! I could curse
The giddy judgement of my blood; that thus
Seduced me to forsake that saint, and mix
My knowledge with this devil. He's fled too,
Untouched by my revenge. Niente, hoa! Enter Altamont.

sp.speaker: Alta.
sp.l: 'Tis Alteza, I know her sinful voice, â(She kneels.)

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: O sir, if anguish, or distress, can make,
An humble heart, behold your lady now;
That shortens thus, her stature, at your feet. â

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.p: What may this forced humility portend?

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: Sciolto (Cruel as the winds in march)
Hath struck, my womanhood, with tyranny,
And scorn. Can fate present so large a test,
Of your true love, (Both to yourself, and me)
As that you minister revenge upon
His life. Go, and salute his recreant heart
With your bright steel, and then obedience claim
Replete with fond idolatry, and love.

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: The fiends are surely married too; for there's
No torment like a wife! false Alteza.

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: So ill I merit charity: that all
My passions argue cunning and pretence.
This is a wise hypocrisy, to hide
Thy lust, or snare me in some guilt, whereby
The Duke may claim my life, and thou receive
More quiet space, t'enjoy Sciolto's limbs.

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: Those angry spirits that reside below,
In flaming ovens, are not more cruel in
Their envy, then am I in hate to him.

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: So soon, dost steep him in thy gall, whom thou
Hast washed i'th warm distilments of thy heart.

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: If ere I knew him, with more guilt, then what
My wishes and my thoughts contained; let wrath
Then make me her experiment, to try
How much of pain, mortality can hear.

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: Thy perjured attestations cease; for though
The hours are few, since first you did confer,
Yet you had both the pregnant thrift, to make
The time advantageous to sin.

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: Express,
Some mercy in your faith, and hear me speak.

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: Keep thy denial between thy blistered lips.
If uttered 'Thou art dead.

sp.speaker: Alta.
sp.l: Dost weep? I sooner thought t'have seen the flint
Supple as sponge; th'obdurate diamond melt
At the glowworms pale eye.

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: How hath the pride
Of courts misled my youth, that you should think
I've lost, all tender compliments of grace?

sp.speaker: Alta.
sp.l: Thou wert a virgin sweet, so precious in
Thy frame, that with the cordage of thy hair
Thou mightst have fettered Kings. Thy voice has marred
The beauties of the night. When thou didst sing
The quiet stars, would fall asleep and wink.
Thou art all discord now: thy glory's dark;
Thy thin, and roseal blood, is turned to ink.

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: I have outlived the help of penitence,
And benefit of hope.

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: Oft have I said
Let's leave the false, the busy world and sleep
Beneath our vines; nature (Not cunning) then,
Augments our wealth; the dew of heaven is cheap,
Nor need we pay for'th suns warm light, if kind
Divinity allow t'each humane soul
A star; our issue we'll increase, until
The bright and numerous throng be all employed.

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: But I am sterile as a wilderness,
My name, is sickness to your memory.

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: Witness you silent powers, the crime is not
Derived from me. T'explain my innocence,
Know, she that here I housed, t'affront thy pride,
Was my chaste sister, not my concubine.

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.p: Then you are loyal still, to th' marriage vow.

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: But; she treads the slimy path. Scoperta,
Is now thy rival in Sciolto's lust.

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: All springs from the ambition of my guilt. â

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: Although thy penitence be rash, it doth
Become thee well, and thou hast quite dissolved
The stony corners of my heart. This night
I purposed thee a cruel death, but now
Rise, and continue mortal still â I'll lay
My mercy on thy lip, and for it take
My last farewell â. I'll never see thee more.

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: This is a mercy that confounds the will
And strength of all my gratitude. O sad
Decree. You have divorced me from your eyes.

sp.speaker: Alta.
sp.l: Two neighbouring lilies whom rude winds disperse
'Mongst restless dust, may sooner meet upon
Their stalks again, and kiss each other in
A second growth, than we our loves renew.

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: Take heed (Sir) how you prophecy! For my
Humility with moist contrition joined,
May hope to wash my leprous stains away.

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: O no! my jealousy is grown so sick, that my
Suspect informs me, it will ne'er be cured.

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: I creep thus to my tomb, indebted for
Your love, till all the drowsy world shall rise
To general accounts; and than my want
Of earlier gratitude will make my debt
A sin âExit.

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: O trivial property of life!
Some do attend the mighty war, and make
Divinity their yoke; till for the sport
Of Kings th' augment the number of the dead.
Some walk in slippery paths of court, and feed
On silent smiles; the gravity of mirth.
Some travail in the search of humane arts,
But knowledge is reserved: she sits so high
In clouds, we cannot reach her with our eye:
Or if with patient steps we to her climb,
Death says we cannot reach her with our time.
For withered age arrives, when numbering on
Our griefs not years; the tedious space of life
We straight accuse. For life is like the span
Forced from a gouty hand; which, as it gains
Extent, and active length, the more it pains. Exit.

div.head: Scene the first.

sp.speaker: Dandolo.
sp.l: My journey was by stealth, else I had brought
With these, legions of Dukes to speak my birth.

sp.speaker: Besognia.
sp.l: My lady 'gins t'enquire (Sir) after sleep,
For it grows late.

sp.speaker: Dandolo.
sp.l: My corporal method
I will disorder, ere I'll miss her view.
This British groat is thine; traffic for pins.

sp.speaker: Besognia.
sp.l: Make the devil your factor; there's a stock
To set up with. Flings it again. Exit.

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: Brother, I wish you would avoid my haunts.
'Tis not for my credit, nor yet for our
Dead fathers, thus to make your person known,
Being you're illegitimate begotten,
By the motion of the evil spirit.

sp.speaker: Punto.
sp.p: Were we his heirs, we'd cause to hasten his decease.

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: D'ye walk like Neptune in a mask,
Attended on by two o'th calm winds?

sp.speaker: Dandolo.
sp.l: They're nobles of a supreme race. This is
Stocccata called, and that punto. They both
Are come to warrant my creation good
Upon the gauntlet of a giant or a whale.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Maintain your birth â were you my father's bawds?

sp.speaker: Stoccata.
sp.l: Alas, you are young (Sir) you know not us!
We cannot swell and rant like things that would
Be rather heard then felt: but we can thrust
Our whineards home, with joy and quiet too.

sp.speaker: Punto.
sp.l: Sweet heart; you are not read i'th' rudiments
Of wrath. You shall perceive some that are loud
And active with their lungs; courage in them
You may suspect: but when you see a cool
And silent anger like to ours, then keep
Your wand'ring hands at home. Soft sir, beware!

sp.speaker: Stoccata.
sp.p: Stay, wilt thou kill him (Punto) or shall I?

sp.speaker: Punto.
sp.l: I've business now of a more serious garb.
Dispatch him thyself. Early tomorrow
I'll do as much for thee on the two zwits.

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: D'ye make no more o'th' infants o'the earth? â

sp.speaker: Stoccata.
sp.l: Fie sir. Draw your weapon in a lady's
Chamber? You still display a courage ill
Brought up, most vainly nurtured (Sir) believe't.

sp.speaker: Punto.
sp.l: Forbid it heaven; but you should have free space
T'imploy your best strength in your defence.
But sir, 'tis sober patience makes us safe.
If now on either's haunch you did confer
A kick; our secret wisdom would direct
Us how to bear it for the time, and in
Our own advantage too.

sp.speaker: Stoccata.
sp.l: Hear sir th'advice of an old shot. I've hit
The mark more than once in my time, and tamed
Many a mad boy too. If either of's
Vouchsafe to greet ye with a hand or foot,
Take it, and be thankful: lest by return
Of wrath, worse do ensue.

sp.speaker: Punto.
sp.l: He's young, stoccata, carve him gently up! â

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: They take me for a capon. What weapons
Fight ye with, demiculuering or drake?

sp.speaker: Stoccata.
sp.l: Steel of Toledo is all we manage â

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: What then remains but Rossa and Molard,
Assault you two, ay, my bastard brother â

sp.speaker: Rossa.
sp.l: Come sir, â

sp.speaker: Molard.
sp.l: We'll jerk you with our iron rods â

sp.speaker: Stoc.
sp.l: Keep your sword warm, it belongs to the scabbard â

sp.speaker: Punto.
sp.l: O sir, your valour still imports some want
Of a discreet and temperate breeding.

sp.speaker: Charintha.
sp.l: His bounty ne'er will give me cause t'advance
My wit: he grows much troublesome.

sp.speaker: Dandolo.
sp.l: Lady! behold two worthies here; dragons
In fight. They come to preach my birth.
They're known to fame.

sp.speaker: Dandolo.
sp.l: I say they're potentates; and they do awe â

sp.speaker: Punto.
sp.l: Signior, you still forget
The quiet and the courteous ways of spleen.

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: I will try your politic patience sir âKicks 'em.

sp.speaker: Punto.
sp.l: You see we still are calm â

sp.speaker: Stoccata.
sp.l: He has but thin
Philosophy that cannot suffer this â

sp.speaker: Charintha.
sp.p: You marmalet count deserves as much too.

sp.speaker: Dandolo.
sp.p: I do oppugn the motion with my scorn.

sp.speaker: Dandolo.
sp.l: Pardon me sir!
I say't aloud; the proudest wight on earth
Shall not kick me, excepting your dear self.

sp.speaker: Niente.
sp.l: I have privacies (Madam) for your ear! â

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: You, and your fierce champions straight remove;
Crawl hence, and be not visible again:

sp.speaker: Punto.
sp.p: Enhance our pay, we'll kill him in the darke.

sp.speaker: Dandolo.
sp.p: Agreed, six ducats you shall number more.

sp.speaker: Niente.
sp.l: The neighbours say, forty sergeants wait his
Departure hence, who give him a new name.

sp.speaker: Charintha.
sp.p: Ha! What do they call him?

sp.speaker: Niente.
sp.l: Florello, and
Report him brother unto Altamont.

sp.speaker: Charintha.
sp.l: My eyes are informed, two faces more allied
In all devotes of view I have not seen.
The younger brother unto Altamont;
Fantastic too as winds, and sillier then
A silenced priest. Fate had much preferred me.

sp.speaker: Besogniae.
sp.l: Madam, it must be he. I've ta'en a strict
Survey of's nose; 'tis so like Altamonts.

sp.speaker: Charintha.
sp.l: He is already so exhaust, that his
Wise bounty can no more be argument
For wit: and now to have this plea for his
Dismission is above my joy. Signior! â

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: Sweet love, I have been bold to give away
One or two of thy farms to these my followers,
They are kind wretches both, and love thee well.

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: Yes saith, they bid me rather than
Thou shouldst thus pine for love to marry thee.

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: Wouldst view my limbs? â

sp.speaker: Charintha.
sp.l: When you do make your christianity
More known, you must be called Florello âª

sp.speaker: Charintha.
sp.l: Forty blue fiends wait to arrest you in
Your passage home.

sp.speaker: Charintha.
sp.l: Could your abusive arts make choice of none
But me? Be sure this visit is your last.

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: I must not, dare not, leave ye, till I've cleared
The errors in this calumny â

sp.speaker: Charintha.
sp.l: Return,
Or you affront my power, and I shall think
Your love, is, as your person, counterfeit.
The strength of all my charity affords
You but this key, which in my orchard gate
You may employ, and free you from th'arrest.
Besognia, I'll to bed. â

div.stage: Florello, Rossa, Molard look ghostly awhile at one another.

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: A sober truth.
Sums I owed when I embarked for Pisa. â

sp.speaker: Rossa.
sp.l: Now shall I, like a melancholy worm,
Feed on raw roots. â

sp.speaker: Molard.
sp.l: Sing canticles of woe!
I must e'en go tag points in a garret. â

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: This key, with rescue o'th' young rapiers of
The law will bring us home.

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: Faith we must all disrobe, our vestments old
Stitch on again, and mortgage these to raise
A sum that may assist my liberty.

sp.speaker: Molard.
sp.l: Creep in our rags of tinder, in our thin
And dusty webs again.

sp.speaker: Rossa.
sp.l: I feel a herd
Of small cattle graze on my left shoulder. â

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: O my forward bounty! There's but sick hope
My jewels will return; since custom shows;
What ladies thus from their dull suitors get
They do preserve as tribute to their wit.

div.stage: Scoperta, and her woman under a canopy.

sp.speaker: Woman.
sp.p: The longer moiety of the night's unspent.

sp.speaker: Scoperta.
sp.l: Since time grew old, he slowly finds his steps
I'th dark: by day he swifter moves. Get thee
To bed; the casements of thine eyes are shut;
imprisoning their dear light.

sp.speaker: Scoperta.
sp.l: Come my sciolto, and confirm the virtue of
Thy faith; or I disperse my soul in sighs,
And make this chair my easy monument. Roads.

sp.speaker: Mervolle.
sp.l: All are departed that to Charintha
Made visit: your servants have begun
Their sleep, and guards are placed upon the gates.

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: Are my bold instruments in ambush laid,
And scattered for the best advantage of
Their concealed action, and their view?

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.p: Expect me then beneath the garden mount.

div.stage: Altamont steals to Scoperta, and shows her his arms besmeared with blood.

sp.speaker: Scoperta.
sp.p: You swelling clouds choke my afflicted sight âª

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: The stars like scattered embers fall. The tears
Of men do meet in seas, and seas o'erwhelm
The earth. Th'amazed herds howl to the sun
For help; whose beams suck moisture up, till he
Hath made the flood his draught; but vomits all
In showers again; such as Deucalion saw!

sp.speaker: Scoperta.
sp.p: Nature (It seems) is frighted from her health.

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: Behold my coral hands, they seem to blush
With guilt of humane sacrifice. Methinks
I look like to a Memphian priest, that had
Dissection made of hecatombs t'appease
Their false divinity. Alteza's dead.

sp.speaker: Scoperta.
sp.l: I want pretence to soothe my faith: else I
Would hope your hands deprived her not of breath?

sp.speaker: Alta.
sp.l: Fathers that feed on sons, and sons that drink
Their mother's blood, reach not that cruelty
which her stern guilt did throw into my breast.

sp.speaker: Scop.
sp.l: May some kind saint, weep o'er your soul until
With holy dew, he wash this sin away.

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: Thou dost misspend thy vestal charity.
I'th solitary age of night I come,
To find those angels that have business now
On earth, in synod here with thee: hoping
I shall receive reward for my just act.

sp.speaker: Scoperta.
sp.l: The hours that gave her opportunity
To err, were known so few; that my belief
Concludes her guiltless of the actual sin.

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: Before the hindmost part of her vexed soul
Forsook her thrilling lips, she did confess,
Sciolto had performed all circumstance
That doth engender man. Sciolto too,
Confirmed her attestation as a truth.

sp.speaker: Scoperta.
sp.l: Be deaf (Sweet heaven) to this. Did Sciolto
Iterate her foul speech?

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: He did, which I,
O'er heard, and forced a passage to his heart.
From its warm throne, I snatched the aching lump,
And threw it straight unto a hungry fiend.

sp.speaker: Scoperta.
sp.l: Is he dead too? The genius of the world
Is sick, all forms must cease.

sp.speaker: Scoperta.
sp.l: O sir, should I restrain the flux, my eyes
Would drop from their loose strings instead of tears.

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.p: This obsequy, doth make compassion sin.

sp.speaker: Scoperta.
sp.l: O Sciolto. Art thou so early fled,
To taste eternity, and unknown fate.

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: Stint thy hoarse dirge, pernicious whore. I had
Some hope, the interview that you enjoyed
Might be enforced by his unruly strength:
But now, I find it was with thy consent
Procured. You've struggled in each others lust.
All now is evident as light.

sp.speaker: Scoperta.
sp.l: I bring
my innocence, to th'clear survey of heaven.

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: Though dull, to men of harsh, strict discipline,
Yet know, I have some cunning in my rage.
I came to fright this secret from thy heart:
My hands I did not bathe in humane blood,
Alteza, and Sciolto are alive.

sp.speaker: Sco.
sp.l: This joy will make my heart dance in my breast. â

sp.speaker: Alta.
sp.l: Sink into th'earth, where sorrow dwells. Ere yond â
Dim morn shall add one hour unto her age,
Sciolto's soul shall take a doubtful flight:
It only stayed to mingle company
With thine. My anger was so just, I would
Not prosecute thy life; until my doubts
Were cleared. Go, go, and number o'er thy beads.

sp.speaker: Scoperta
sp.l: Is there in all your veins, no drop (Unmixed
With Gaul) that from our mother is derived,
And so may tempt compassion from your breast?

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: Alteza mourns, as if t'expiate
A nation with her grief. Hadst thou revealed
Such penitence, it might have softened my
Decree. But thou art sour and stern of soul.

sp.speaker: Scoperta.
sp.p: No mercy, for our noble mother's sake?

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: My mother when she lay, a cold pattern for
The figure on her tomb, spent her last breath
In praise of thee. Quoth she; for my sake use
Thy sister well: th'acqaintance that she hath
In heaven is great. I'th blossom of her growth
She shall o'ercome the eyes of men, and in
Her age, she shall have skill in prophecy.
But oh false lore! Our mother kind, (Whom I
A sibyl held) thou now hast proved a witch.

sp.speaker: Scoperta.
sp.l: I am too weak to force from your belief
Mistakes so strong.

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: Go pray, the hours are swift:
I've purposed thee a prisoner here till my
Return. â this is a sickly rheum âª and not
Compunction in my eyes. â

sp.speaker: Scoperta.
sp.l: The last of all
My merits shall be called obedience to
Your will: if you do owe a kindness to
Yourself; think on religion and the laws. Exit.

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: Nature do thou direct my spleen. The laws
Are sinfully contrived. Justice should weigh
The present crime, not future inference
On deeds. But now they cheapen blood: 'tis spilt
To punish the example, not the guilt.
Religion too, on our Italian earth,
Grows like the cedar big and high; but yields
No fruit. The abject race of men she doth
Confound with hope, and bids them not obey,
T'augment humility, but her own sway. Exit.

div.stage: Enter Mervolle, Sciolto, and three mutes.

sp.speaker: Mervolle.
sp.p: Your strength does but entangle ye the more.

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: I'll not be trussed (Sir) like a pullet thus â

sp.speaker: Mervolle.
sp.l: Leave nothing that can minister defence.
Disarm him of his pins.

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: Pare my nails too. â

sp.speaker: Mervolle.
sp.l: You shall be angered straight, till you bestow
The time to bite 'em off. Soon as we spied
You scaling o'er the orchard wall; we guessed
The hopes of your visit. There have been snares
Laid for your feet, ere since you left the house. â

div.stage: Exeunt Mervolle, mutes, having rifled him of his pistols and his sword.

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: There is some danger in this chance, my dull
Heart beats with slow, and ominous leisure. â

sp.speaker: Scoperta.
sp.l: Pale planet shine! It must be he. My ears
Persuade me they o'ertook his voice. Sir, sir! â

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: Ha! Scoperta? A cruel destiny
Hath murdered all our joy. endeavouring an
Add all for stealth of thee, I was surprised,
Disarmed; even here ith' presence of my stars.

sp.speaker: Scoperta.
sp.l: There's not a star in all the firmament
Belongs to us.

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: O none! Or if there be,
Their influence is so weak that at
This distance babes may blow 'em out. Sure our
Creation we have taken unknown to fate.

sp.speaker: Scoperta.
sp.l: Our love was of too nimble growth unless
Philosophy give hope, that after death
We may converse; this is the last of all
Our interviews.

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: That fatal prophecy
Will shake my soul from out my flesh; and like
Some tame hermit I shall unwounded die.

sp.speaker: Scoperta.
sp.l: The word that's heard abbreviates our discourse
And live: the sand that limits both is fallen
Into the reach of number now: and I
Have spent with thee the hasty time prefixed
For a devout employment of my beads.
The murderers are within.

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: Grim wild horror!
Hast thou no weapons there that I may use
T'anihilate their vigour and their shape?

sp.speaker: Scoperta.
sp.l: Unto thy lips I'd throw a kiss; but with
The strings of my poor solitary lute
They've bound my hands! â

sp.speaker: Sciolto
sp.l: O my hot rage! I could
Spit fire till I enkindle yonder grove,
Raising a flame that might perplex the earth,
And make 'em think heaven had dropped a planet.

sp.speaker: Scoperta.
sp.l: And I could weep until I quenched that flame,
And drew suspicion that a second flood
Was come to drown mortality again!

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: This sudden elevation of the soul âª
presageth death: as if it practised how
To rise, and climb ere she begins her flight.

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: I'll be as calm as are Arabian winds.
Scoperta, stay; unheard we will converse. â

sp.speaker: Sco.
sp.l: They come, they come, dear love, for evermore farewell âª

div.stage: The mutes snatch her from the window.

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: O for the giant race, to help me heave
Those mountains up; that I might bury this
Proud structure and myself! Yond burly Oak
(Whose roots reach hell) I'll manage till I pound
And batter all the marble into flower. â

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: You have o'erheard, what will your knowledge grieve.

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: Her soul is ill prepared âª

sp.speaker: Mervolle.
sp.l: I gave command
They should awhile delay her death, lest want
Of leisure might destroy her penitence.

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: Remain within the summons of my call:
And leave me here. I charge thee by thy vow,
And our friendships dear use, that thou depart.

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: Some call me Altamont.
I've seen thee walk armed like a magazine âª
With small artillery entrenched: but thou
Art fitly now prepared for sufferance.

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: Not thy tame sacrifice, but victory
I'll be. For naked as I am I will
Resist my death; and since unfurnished to
Revenge, yet I shall trouble thy best strength. â

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: Sciolto, though, thou merit treachery âª
And opposition that, by darkest stealth,
ãâã ãâã of thy luxurious soul,
yet I will give thee fair and equal game.

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: Stay. This I will perform âª
And 'tis to know the rigour of thy might,
What wondrous flame and spirits do possess
Thy spacious breast.

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: I'd learn the providence and justice of
My fate; try if they'll let me fall before
Th'encounter of thy bestial strength; thou that
Augment'st thy sins t'o'ercome the memory
Of heaven: in silly hope, th'accompts may be
Unwillingly surveyed, because they're long.
Receive thy sword. â

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: If whilst we struggle in the pride of hope
