Thou canst so weaken my defence, that I
Become disarmed; thy liberty is gained.

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: With solemn penitence I could accuse
My crimes 'gainst thee: but grief's akin to fear.
This great demeanour of thy spleen divides
Th'intent of gratitude. I know not which
T'afford thee most, my envy, or my love.

sp.speaker: Alta.
sp.l: The moon hath now put on her brightest robe;
My anger too, doth carry fire enough
To light us to the charge âª guard well thy heart. â

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.p: A little respite give, â must we needs fight?

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: You then would cozen me of my revenge? â

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.p: Yet stay! â know I do love thy sister well.

sp.speaker: Alta.
sp.l: Mark (Sweet heaven) with what exalted triumph
He boasts the foul remembrance of his sin. â

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: Stiff as a column! â

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: Th'arcadian wrestler told
Young Theseus so; but he did yield as if
His sinews had been made of silk. So fierce? â

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: I'll work thy strength so low, that virgins shall
have power to shackle thee with spinners threads â

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: Thus I will bore thy flesh, till thou become
Transparent as a sieve â

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: This closure hath
Entangled us, let's make another charge?

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: Even thus divided billows part, that they
May meet in greater foam â

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: Wilt thou not bleed?
Not yet? â I skirmish with unbodied air.

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: Thy guilt betrays thy hand unto mistakes,
And thus my injured spirits greet thy life â

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.p: That wound gapes like to a yawning giant.

sp.speaker: Altamont
sp.l: So hot is thy lascivious blood, that as
I sprinkle it, it scalds my hands â

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: I reel
Before thy breast, and stumble at a wart â

sp.speaker: Alta.
sp.p: Thy sword's my captive now. Mervolle, hoa!

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: I have some courage yet, left in my teeth,
If thou art kind, come nearer with my throat â

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: O the celestial powers are just. See there,
He bleeds like to a spring, that borders on
The Rubicke sea, whilst I remain untouched.

sp.speaker: Mervolle.
sp.p: Has he not lost the benefit of breath?

sp.speaker: Alta.
sp.l: Stop all his wounds, and give him time to spend
The rest of's moisture in repentant tears â

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.p: My wounds closed up, what means this courtesy?

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: That thou mightst leisure have to pray. Be sure
(Mervolle.)when's devotions have arrived
Unto a powerful length; you strangle him.

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.p: Can thy young honour stoop to such low flight?

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: Unto resistance equal, I exposed
My strength, to try thy courage and my fate.
This was my justice to myself: justice
I'll give to thee: thy crimes do merit death.

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: O sooth my last ambition then âª be thou
My executioner.

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: Thou art disarmed,
Thy blooming honours now are withered on
Thy crest. I should deprive my anger of
Her fame, to be thy active opposite.

sp.speaker: Sciolto âª
sp.l: Scoperta, stay. My soul shall hover straight
With thine. Stay for me in the milky-path.

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: Let Italy avowch the just demean
Of my revenge. Dull Britons know no wrath.
Th'unskilful youth, that equal duel give
To him that first incensed the blood; but tempt
The courtesy of fate, such take delight
To stroke abuse, pay injuries, with right.

sp.speaker: Mervolle.
sp.l: This way (Sir) leads unto your grave. You shall
Have space, to gain some friendship with the saints â

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: A sudden frost congeals my heart; I shrink
Like crooked age; I am unwieldy on
My joints, as if my veins were empty grown. â
Wounded. His point has stolen into my breast.
O help. I've yet some use for life. Th'nice search,
I made to know heavens secret justice is
Avenged. (Bold earth!) I weep into the sea,
And sigh t'augment the winds. Repentance is
An immaterial salve, it cures th'unsound
Diseased soul, but not the body's wound.

div.head: Scene the first.
div.stage: Enter Niente, Alteza in her night gown.

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: A guard upon my gates, and have they there
Been placed ere since the first arrival of
The night?

sp.speaker: Niente.
sp.l: Mervolle keeps the keys, he'll let
No servant be awake about the house.

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: The sun begins to bathe i'th' mornings tears âª
Hast thou Lucio called, and bid Pytho mix
With him in a sad song?

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: No more (Niente) shalt thou service do
For me: last night I told thee I had lost
My vanity: that courtly lady serve
Who finds it first. But lest thy wants augment
Thy sins, my charity affords thee this â

sp.speaker: Niente.
sp.p: Well I'm resolved to mend, or become worse.

lg.l: This lady, ripe, and calm, and fresh,
Must now forsake both time, and flesh,
T'add light to some small star.
Whilst yet alive, each star decayed âª
But death leads beauty to a shade
More cold more dark, than night.
The saucy faith of man doth blind
To destine all his abject kind
But ask not bodies (Doomed to die)
Since knowledge is, but sorrow's spy,
It is not safe to know.

sp.speaker: Mervolle.
sp.l: Howle, howl, until you wake the inhabitants
Of graves! till you disquiet all the spheres;
And put harmonious nature out of tune,

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: What means this fatal summon, that doth make
Amazement cold, as is iberian ice.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Great Altamont (Your lord) who still was prompt
To curb th'incitements of your wrath; threw wise
advantage from his reach, and struggled with
The bold sciolto, in an equal war.

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: Down holy flame. When hope doth sicken so,
I would not have the power to prophecy.

sp.speaker: Mervolle.
sp.l: The surly lion, and the testy boar,
Did never maintain, resistance with like fierce
And ruinous return of strength: for from
Their eyes such lightning flew, that villagers
(Whose early labours tilled the earth) did think
Rash Phaeton did scourge the fiery teem
Again. Sciolto chipped âª gagged with wounds;
Did bleed away his strength. This his false sword
Your husband bade me prostrate at your feet â
And 'tis the last memorial of his love.

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: Ambiguous history! He conqueror,
Yet this the last memorial of his love!

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Wise heaven did mock your Altamont: for whilst
O'er joyed with victory, he spies in's breast
A large deep wound, and thence his soul took flight.

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: O my poor lord! how soon hast thou begun
Thy immortality. The hasty spark
So upward mounts, and then no more is seen.

sp.speaker: Mervolle.
sp.l: I'th' last remainder of his dying speech,
He briefly told his testament; which doth
Contain employments sad, and such as you
Must actuate straight. To please his ghost, show now
A little loyalty and love, rise, and
Be conducted by my slow steps. I will
Inform your knowledge all that he enjoined

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: Th'obedience which I scanted to his life,
Unto his memory I'll strictly pay.

sp.speaker: Mervolle.
sp.l: You have a loss that doth outspeak complaint âª
If sweet and pliant discipline of courts,
If feats of mighty war, or sober arts
Advance th'esteem of humane quality;
'Tis fit your Altamont we strive to raise,
Above the charity or skill of praise âª

div.stage: Enter Florello, Rossa, Molard, in their old habits, Dandolo, stoccata, punto, bound.

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.p: Who did assist your passage to this walk?

sp.speaker: Rossa.
sp.l: Mervolle sir, with whom we used your name.
Do you observe the count, and his two lean
Janissaries?

sp.speaker: Rossa.
sp.l: Certain stratagems (Sir) have been levelled
'Gainst the prerogative of your life royal.
Molard. Ere since the hope of day âª they waited your
Descent from the cloister bridge: but doubting
Their own courage, and meeting us disguised,
Thus in our original weeds; they would
Have bribed us for two pistolets t'assist
The prosecution of your death. Our grace
And strength bound them to their good behaviour.

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: They walk like caterpillars on a leaf. â
Yield me the cause why you contrived my death.

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: Give me a knife! â

sp.speaker: Rossa.
sp.p: Here is one belonged to Hans van Geulicke.

div.stage: Florello cuts Dandolos bonds, and gives him the knife.

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: Take yourself solemnly aside and cut
Your throat! do't straight, and neatly too, y'had best.

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: Have you three throats, can you revive as oft
As you are killed, to take new punishment,
That thus you mutiny 'gainst kind reason?

sp.speaker: Dandolo.
sp.l: These thousand years 't has been observed, th'eldest
Brothers of her house (Sir) could ne'er endure
To cut their throats.

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: 'Tis fit (Dear count) that you
Must die; I'm else unjust unto myself.

sp.speaker: Dandolo.
sp.l: With sapient arts, we will project to save
Th'reputation of your justice.

sp.speaker: Dandolo.
sp.l: I will promulgate I am dead, and both,
My champions here shall swear't.

sp.speaker: Stoccata.
sp.l: We'll venture one
Commandment to save another sir.

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: This cannot satisfy. Howe'er (Sir count)
If you will patiently accept your death.
I'll furnish ye with guides, for your last jaunt.
You punto, and stoccata too! No more
Of your philosophy. Fix brow, to brow,
Knock out, each others brains, and show your lord
The way, unto th'elysian-field. Do it
At first encounter too; for I'm in haste â

sp.speaker: Stoccata.
sp.l: 'Slight sir, I ne'er was in Elysium, I.
Nor should I find the way thither, though signior
Argos, lent me ninety nine of his eyes.

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.p: Then punto shall be conduct to ye both.

sp.speaker: Punto.
sp.l: Good signior, any courtesy but this
You may command. You still do most presume
Upon the calmest, and th'easy nature.

sp.speaker: Rossa.
sp.l: They all are pictures to th'law. If you'll
Bestow 'em but as prisoners unto us,
They shall suffer, or give us large ransom.

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: How? A ransom? These two are poorer than
Carthusian-monkes: lean as a Romish lent.
Slaves, who pretend sickness, that they may lie
In hospitals to steal the sheets. Acorns
They eat, such as westphalia-hoggs do scorn.

sp.speaker: Rossa.
sp.p: The count (Sir) will untie his strings for 'em.

sp.speaker: Dandolo.
sp.p: Ransom, I'll give: for I do hate to die.

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: The ransom must
Be small. Suffle 'em together: and pack
'Em hence. I will not hear a syllable
Of thanks. Rossa, see 'em horsed for Milan.

sp.speaker: Charintha.
sp.l: O dismal change! does your victorious sword
Hang now on aged belt of bandoleer?
Is your high plume moulted to a sprig, small,
As if 'twere made o'th wing of a beetle.

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: Who can resist the frowns of destiny?
My sufferance gives my merits their reward.

sp.speaker: Charintha.
sp.l: Your speech was wont to be in a more high
Exalted key: loud as a gulf! Your heart
Was full of jigs, and your feet did wander
Even like autumn's dust.

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: Affect so much
Humility as may employ your thoughts
With more compassion on my ruinous fall.

sp.speaker: Charintha.
sp.p: I threw on you perpetual banishment.

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: I'm come to manifest the sin of my
Disguise âª though it proceeded more from hope
T'enjoy your person then your wealth. Witness
Each nimble register of humane thoughts!

sp.speaker: Charintha.
sp.p: 'Has got a sweet and powerful way in speech.

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: This is my real shape, in which I do
Appear, a thin and withered soldier born,
I'th' later age of war: when glory's sick,
And honour trivial as the spleen of babes.

sp.speaker: Charintha.
sp.p: He was not wont to use this dialect.

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: Grant now (Thou beauteous wealth of Italy)
An expiation for my crimes; for know,
I would be clean when I shall dedicate
My future vows to th'absent altar of
Thy heart: lest I do lose the use of my
Idolatry; and make repentance sin.

sp.speaker: Charintha.
sp.l: Do all harmonious gifts reside within
Such course and humble weeds?

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: Destroy me not
With scorn: I know you ladies most delight
I'th' frail surface of the body, in name,
and guilded pomp, which was the fatal cause
I practised them on you:

sp.speaker: Charintha.
sp.l: Y' endear the worst
Of fashion unto us, by making it
A custom in yourselves. If men did not
Provide such follies for our sight, we knew
Not where to find their use, for they digest
Them first, than they become our nourishment.

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: Vain men. We alter our creation so
With female shapes, that heaven scarce knows its stamp
And nature (That distinction still commands
T'each sex) forgets the work of her own hands.

sp.speaker: Charintha.
sp.l: I ne'er beheld a feature masculine
Till now: had you but thus appeared unto
My first survey, I might have loved in haste,
And yet excused the rashness of my eyes.
I 'gin to feel some danger in my stay.

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: Ere you depart, a small memorial from
Your hands, I crave, to wear upon my crest,
That it may tempt kind fate to look on me,
When I in glorious battle strive; and
I will absent myself for evermore.

sp.speaker: Charintha.
sp.l: I nothing keep for such sad use, as to
Deprive me of so sweet a miracle.

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: Grant my request, or I'll pursue your steps

sp.speaker: Charintha.
sp.l: If you continue still to beg, I fear
My bounty will prove rash: and I shall give
So much of love, as you can never repay. â

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: O my auspicious stars! Should I not now
Make use of your good influence, I were
Unworthy of your care. âEnter Mervolle.

sp.speaker: Mervolle.
sp.l: The choice you make
Can ne'er deserve your chaste and lawful fire
She is Florello of a heart and strain
Too insolent for nuptial happiness:

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: Thou hast been called my friend. But if thy spleen
Continue a dislike of her, I'll blow thee from
my memory, and with my chiefest strength
I'll punish thy mistake â

sp.speaker: Mervolle.
sp.l: A desolate grief
Will more become thy breast then this proud rage.
Thy brother's dead, and his decease caused by
Her sister's pride.

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: Into my ears thou hast a horror poured
That hath already stiffened every hair
On my amazed skull into a reed.

sp.speaker: Charintha.
sp.l: Wilt thou neglect to cherish the swift growth
Of our new loves?

sp.speaker: Mervolle.
sp.l: Like to her sister she
But counterfeits a passionate esteem,
That thy fond nature she might tempt beneath
Her rule. If Altamont be dear unto
Thy thought, leave her, and straight attend his hearse,
That in the chapel waits thy obsequy. Exit.

sp.speaker: Charintha.
sp.l: Th' inspired needle's not more true unto
The North, the sun to his diurnal race,
Nor rivers to the main; then I to thee.

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: Sorrow and love, my senses do divide.
If I remain with thee, then only love
I serve, if with sad steps, I tread the way
Unto my brother's hearse, I both obey. Exit.

sp.speaker: Charin.
sp.l: Thou dost requite the scorns which I did throw
On thy first love. My destiny must needs
Be tragic now: since the contracted scope
Of all my joy, rests in diseased hope. Exit âª

sp.speaker: Mervolle.
sp.l: Behold the throne, your lord commanded me
Prepare: and here you must be pleased to sit. â

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: Can this advancement ought refer to your
Delight, or to my lords last testament?

sp.speaker: Mervolle.
sp.l: Justice hath laid her sword within your reach:
and you have power to sheath it so; that where
You execute, you may a murder do,
Or sacrifice. Bring the delinquents in.

div.stage: Enter Sciolto, Scoperta, at several doors, each led in, bound and hoodwinked, by two mutes.

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: Thy spirit Altamont ascended with
The love of all my chiefest orisons.

sp.speaker: Mervolle.
sp.l: These two were by your husband's jealousy âª
And hate, ordained for death: but ere that we
Could actuate his will; his noble breast
Received a wound, that bade him straight provide
For is own eternity. The last of all
His speech, referred them both unto your power.
You may appoint them live or die: and I'm
Obliged by vow, to see performed what you
Command.

sp.speaker: Mervolle.
sp.l: Your jewels, and your wealth, I have packed up,
To ease our flight, when we have finished
This usurpation of the laws. Let them
Enjoy their eyes; that they may know their judge.

sp.speaker: Mervolle.
sp.p: Keep them divided from each others reach âª

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: I thought thy beauties had been dark and cold,
And thou'dst (Ere this) begun an easy sleep
Within thy silent grave.

sp.speaker: Scoperta.
sp.l: And I supposed thee fled
A harbinger to heaven: with purpose to
Bespeak my billet near to thine.

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: Since this sad night, did blind the drowsy world,
They thus have manacled my strength. They've watched
My hardy violence so tame, that now
each feathered forester roosts in my beard.

sp.speaker: Scoperta.
sp.l: We cannot (Sir) be mortal long; therefore
Receive a hope our sufferance will cease.

sp.speaker: Mervolle.
sp.l: Sciolto, now requite the leisure I
Have given thy penitence, by rendering straight
Unto the world, how far thou didst corrupt
These ladies with thy guilt. For know, I still
Persuaded Altamont thy lust enjoyed
No more, than what concerned wishes or hope.
And I was ushered to'th belief of this,
By knowledge of those secret spies which he
Employed to watch your personal removes,
About the house: whose labours ever missed
Of finding that success he prophesied.

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: I do confess m'imagination once
Did sin against them both: but if it ere
Extended unto act; let me lose heaven âª

sp.speaker: Mervolle.
sp.l: If Altamont were now alive, he would
Permit this utterance clear his faith. Madam,
You hear that he Scoperta vindicates
By oath; though his own crime doth carry an
Import more evident, and black; but yet
When you behold his feature, and his youth,
Your mercy may conceive 'twere pity that
He should so soon depart from time and flesh.

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: Sir, you have skill to know my womanhood
Is weak as ignorance, or sleep. Why should
You seat me here, thus to dispose of law:
That never knew any justice, but revenge.

sp.speaker: Mervolle.
sp.p: Your sentence I am bound to execute.

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: Have I not heard you say, my husband did
Ordain them both for death? 'twould ill become
The duty of my knowledge t'alter his
Decree.

sp.speaker: Mervolle.
sp.l: Keep your intent, I will usurp
The office of your tongue. Mutes, strangle them.

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: If in thy functions, gentle nature claim
an interest, let us embrace, and use
Solemnity, before we do forsake
Each others view.

sp.speaker: Mervolle.
sp.l: I grant what you
Request: make your performance short; whilst I
Reveal m'opinions (Lady) to your ear.

div.stage: Sciolto, and Scoperta kneel to each other.

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: O Scoperta! this is the last of all
Our busy dreams; what we possess is but
Imaginary now: thy shadow I,
Embrace, not thee: for like to it, thou'lt fly
From my enjoyment, and no more be seen! â

sp.speaker: Scoperta.
sp.l: So much of various fate, so soon expressed
Two lovers yet never knew; since sympathy
First dwelled on earth.

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: Ere long we must be cold,
Cold, cold my love, and wrapped in stubborn sheets
Of lead: housed in a deep, a gloomy vault;
Where no society will mix with us,
But what shall quicken from our tainted limbs.

sp.speaker: Scoperta.
sp.l: Whilst still there's noise, and business in the world;
Whilst still the wars grow loud, and battles join;
Whilst Kings their Queens salute in ivory beds.

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: But o! how many ages may succeed
In heaven's dark calendar; ere we again
Material be, and meet in our warm flesh?

sp.speaker: Sco.
sp.l: And whether that our souls, when they're preferred
To taste eternity will ever think
Upon the bargains of our humane love,
Is unto me a desolate suspense.

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: Philosophy doth seem to laugh upon
Our hopes, and wise divinity belies
Our knowledge, with our faith: jealous nature,
Hath locked, her secrets in a cabinet,
which time ne'er saw: and he that in it pries
Unto religion forfeits his bold eyes.

sp.speaker: Scoperta.
sp.l: Our reason frights our senses to distrust.
My lips do beg from thine a legacy â

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: O sad account. How is my bounty now
Exhaust: this is the last I ere shall give â

sp.speaker: Mervolle.
sp.l: Blind them again and stay their deaths awhile.
Madam, your knowledge is already taught
Scoperta's innocence. Sciolto's deed
Stands near your punishment; but distant far
From remedy. Mark, his goodly feature.
With what magnificence he's built? Besides
This morn âª his uncle too (The wealthiest of
Our senators) is dead, and has been pleased
T'entitle him his heir.

sp.speaker: Mervolle.
sp.l: Think how you loved him once. He will (To save
His life) discard Scoperta's interest,
And marry you: a happiness complete
For both

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: Slaves. Stretch now your cordage out,
Pull till my eyes do start like bullets from my skull,
Murdering where they fly â

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: Hold. hold. â did my
Dead lord bid you perform, what I decree?

sp.speaker: Mervolle.
sp.p: He did: and I assured it with my vows.

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: Hear then without resistance of my breath,
Sciolto is condemned by law; as known
The fatal instrument that did deprive
My lord, of precious life; so he must die.
'Twere fit my care affected mercy in
Scoperta's dome; she's sister to my lord:
But her sweet innocence doth make her safe.
She must remain among the living still;
And in her room, I do condemn myself.
For my stern pride, was the original cause
of this black tragedy. Kind ãâ¦ã
Esteem your vows, see my edict ãâã âª
And give me privilege first to ãâã
Its wrath âShe descends.

sp.speaker: Mervolle.
sp.l: This carries wonder in't

sp.speaker: Scoperta.
sp.l: I'll not resign these bonds of death, unless
Sciolto share in the compassion too â

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: Give me your pardon (Gentle maid). I have
Deprived you of a brother that deserved
More pyramids, then all th'egyptian Kings.
Instead of him, receive my prayers, my wealth.
When o'er his herse you raise a monument,
And fix my marble-figure near to his,
Create me weeping. â I shall go, with so
Much sorrow, to my grave, that being dead,
My ashes will have power to penetrate
The stones. Release this pious lady and
Perform your execution upon me â

div.stage: One o'th' mutes pulls of his vizard and discover himself to be Altamont.

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: Away you dreadful ministers of death.
The laurel sprig, the myrtle nicely wreathed
In coronets, my love deserves; for she
Is grown too good for earth. â

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: My Altamont. âShe sinks.

div.stage: Mervolle unmussles, and unbinds Sciolto, and Scoperta, who straight embrace each other.

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: This deceit brings wonder, great as our joy.
They that divide us now, must use the strength
Of swelling floods, and help of thunder too â

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: Put all thy beauties on again, and smile
At the return of our long absent love:
My wound is closed, and will have instant cure â

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: The earth groaned at my fall, so heavy are
My sins, so much they did increase my weight.

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: Rise gently like a flame, from incense sprung.
Mervolle, to appease my jealousy
Ordained me this disguises that I might hear
How in your sentence you behaved your love
To me: hadst thou continued false, I had
Increased the anger of thy fate: but now
Thou art endeared unto my heart again. â

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: Sir, I have hope my future loyalty
Will manifest, your mercy well bestowed. â

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: Scoperta, thou'lt excuse the carriage of
My doubts, I looked on thee with th'eyes of love,
And love is still too strict in her survey. â

sp.speaker: Scoperta.
sp.l: My memory would sin, should it record
Ought that might nourish my dislike of you:
You made me taste of sorrow, not of wrath.

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.l: 'Tis I, that have most needful use of your
Kind charity: forget my errors past,
And to oblige my future gratitude
Give Hymen leave to know your sister for
My wife. My uncle's death hath lent me power
Still to maintain her in such quality
As shall become my dear respects to you,
The greatness of her virtue, and her blood.

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: Take her, and be as tender of her health,
As heaven hath o'er thy wounds; which in their cure
Express much miracle. â my joy's so swell
My breast, that I do find there's danger in
Delight. How blessed Mervolle are thy arts?

sp.speaker: Mervolle.
sp.p: Some angels care assisted the success.

sp.speaker: Charintha.
sp.l: Not Altamont's return to life, nor yet
Sciolto's and Scoperta's glad reprieve
Nor all the joys in reconcilement of
your loves expressed, can my cold senses please:
Florello is unkind. â

sp.speaker: Besognia.
sp.l: The little God
Hath lately pricked her with his bawdy shaft.

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: Tell me Charintha, is thy love sincere:
Such as i'th simple youth of nature is
Exchanged by lovers with a harmless plight?

sp.speaker: Charintha.
sp.l: It is sincere, as holy hermit's vows,
And true, as their confession at their deaths.

sp.speaker: Mervolle.
sp.p: Appear Florello, and receive thy doom.

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: It was Mervolle's care thus to assure
Thy mistress real love, and constancy
Ere thou shouldst give too much of thine away.
But now receive her from Alteza's hand. â

sp.speaker: Alteza.
sp.l: Charintha, thy election is so safe
Thou never wilt repent the judgement of
Thy sight. He cannot be so near allied
Unto the blood of Altamont, but he
Must needs participate in virtue too.

sp.speaker: Charintha.
sp.l: We will embrace each other until age,
Deprive our courteous sinews of extent. â

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: The gentle turtle shall direct us how
T'augment our loves; the eagle to renew
Our youth, and we will strive to imitate
The crooked vine in our increase. â

sp.speaker: Altamont.
sp.l: Joy, joy!
The firmament is now unmasked, and each
Of us, hath found his star.

sp.speaker: Florello.
sp.l: My loved sister,
I have o'erheard the story of your griefs,
And from this noble signior, I must beg
A faith endeared, the name of brother too.

sp.speaker: Sciolto.
sp.p: You shall be precious to my eyes as day.

div.stage: Enter Rossa, Molard, fantastically clothed in Dandolo's habit.

sp.speaker: Molard.
sp.l: The great Dandolo and his giant whelps
Are mounted on a mule.

sp.speaker: Rossa.
sp.l: Naked they ride
As scouts of Tartary they're victualled with
A single egg.

sp.speaker: Florel.
sp.l: They're such your knowledge shall affect: they must
Enjoy what I achieve. Dull men, o'war,
The trophy of my victory behold,
She's mine: bow, and do homage to her lip. â

sp.speaker: Alt.
sp.l: Still thou dost mourn (Alteza) like a dove. Soft music âª
Hark, hark how the roman-organ seems
T'invoke the Thracian lyre; the cymbals of
Judea, call castilian-cornets forth,
And german-viols wake the Tuscan lute âª
The sacred noise attend, that whilst we hear,
Our souls may dance into each others ear.
